perturbation.original_text: Service Provider shall perform the maintenance portion of the Services in a clean, safe, efficient and  environmentally reasonable manner and maintain the SEF in good operating and mechanical condition in accordance with this Agreement and (i)  all applicable laws and permits, (ii) all applicable express warranties and guarantees provided by manufacturers, suppliers, or Service Providers who  provided materials or labor under the Engineering, Procurement and Construction Agreement dated September 30, 2009 (the "EPC Agreement")  for the SEF subject to the terms and limitations thereof, and (iii) all manufacturer's maintenance instructions and specifications.
perturbation.changed_text: Service Provider shall endeavor to perform the maintenance portion of the Services in a generally clean, safe, efficient and environmentally reasonable manner and to maintain the SEF in reasonably good operating and mechanical condition in accordance with this Agreement and (i)  applicable laws and permits, (ii) applicable express warranties and guarantees provided by manufacturers, suppliers, or Service Providers who  provided materials or labor under the Engineering, Procurement and Construction Agreement dated September 30, 2009 (the "EPC Agreement")  for the SEF subject to the terms and limitations thereof, and (iii) manufacturer's maintenance instructions and specifications.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires the service provider to perform the maintenance in a 'clean, safe, efficient, and environmentally reasonable manner'. The modified text introduces ambiguity by changing 'shall perform' to 'shall endeavor to perform' and 'maintain the SEF in good operating and mechanical condition' to 'maintain the SEF in reasonably good operating and mechanical condition'. The terms 'endeavor', 'generally' and 'reasonably good' are vague and open to interpretation, making it harder to enforce specific standards.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 3203 requires employers to establish, implement, and maintain an effective Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP), including procedures for ensuring a safe and healthful workplace. The ambiguous language weakens the requirement for maintaining a safe environment, potentially contradicting this regulation.

perturbation.original_text: 1.5 Permits. Service Provider shall identify, procure, obtain, maintain and comply with all permits that may be required under applicable laws for or  in connection with the performance of Services (and Non-Covered Services as actually provided by Service Provider) and that need to be  procured, obtained and maintained by or in the name of Service Provider. Owner shall provide Service Provider with such assistance and  cooperation as may reasonably be required in order to obtain and maintain all such Permits. Service Provider shall submit copies of all applications  for, and proposed forms of, all such Permits to Owner with sufficient time to allow for Owner's review and approval.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.5 Permits. Service Provider shall attempt to identify, procure, obtain, maintain and comply with most permits that may be required under applicable laws for or  in connection with the performance of Services (and Non-Covered Services as actually provided by Service Provider) and that may need to be  procured, obtained and maintained by or in the name of Service Provider. Owner shall provide Service Provider with assistance and  cooperation as deemed necessary in order to obtain and maintain some of such Permits. Service Provider may submit copies of applications  for, and proposed forms of, all such Permits to Owner when feasible, for Owner's review and approval.
perturbation.explanation: The modification introduces ambiguity by changing 'shall identify, procure, obtain, maintain and comply' to 'shall attempt to identify, procure, obtain, maintain and comply with most permits'. The terms 'attempt' and 'most' are vague, suggesting that not all permits will necessarily be obtained. Also, replacing 'as may reasonably be required' to 'as deemed necessary' weakens the cooperation needed to obtain the permits. Changing 'Service Provider shall submit copies of applications' to 'Service Provider may submit copies of applications' makes the application process vague.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) requires a rigorous environmental review process and obtaining necessary permits for projects that may have significant environmental impacts. The amended text allows for discretionary compliance with permit requirements, which may not meet the CEQA requirements.

perturbation.original_text:
1.7 Personnel Standards.

(a) Service Provider's employees shall be qualified (and if required by applicable law, licensed, certified or registered) and experienced in the  functions to which they are assigned and shall meet the requirements of all permits, all applicable laws and the then-current SEF maintenance  manuals (to the extent copies of which have been provided to Service Provider by Owner). If requested, Service Provider shall provide to Owner  evidence of the competence of such personnel including details of their previous experience and qualifications. If Owner or User reasonably  determines an employee of Service Provider to be under-qualified, disruptive, non-cooperative or otherwise undesirable at the Premises, Owner or  User may request the immediate removal of such employee from the Premises for any existing or future delivery of the Services and the replacement  of such employee with a different employee of Service Provider; provided that Owner or User, as the case may be, will use commercially reasonable  efforts to provide reasonable notice to Service Provider of the need for such proposed removal.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.7 Personnel Standards.

(a) Service Provider's employees should be reasonably qualified (and if required by applicable law, licensed, certified or registered) and generally experienced in the  functions to which they are assigned and should meet the general requirements of most permits, applicable laws and the then-current SEF maintenance  manuals (to the extent copies of which have been provided to Service Provider by Owner). Upon request, Service Provider may provide to Owner  evidence of the general competence of such personnel including details of their previous experience and qualifications. If Owner or User generally determines an employee of Service Provider to be potentially under-qualified, disruptive, non-cooperative or otherwise undesirable at the Premises, Owner or  User may suggest the gradual removal of such employee from the Premises for any existing or future delivery of the Services and the possible replacement  of such employee with a different employee of Service Provider; provided that Owner or User, as the case may be, will attempt to provide reasonable notice to Service Provider of the need for such proposed removal.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall be qualified' to 'should be reasonably qualified', 'shall meet the requirements of all permits' to 'should meet the general requirements of most permits', 'Service Provider shall provide to Owner evidence' to 'Service Provider may provide to Owner evidence' introduces ambiguity. The original text makes personnel standards mandatory and easily enforceable while the modified text makes it ambiguous. Also, by changing 'may request the immediate removal' to 'may suggest the gradual removal' it contradicts the need for instant action.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Labor Code Section 2802 requires employers to indemnify employees for all necessary expenditures or losses incurred by the employee in direct consequence of the discharge of their duties. Reducing standards makes it difficult to protect employees and can cause conflicts with this labor code.
